intro: Vaccinium macgregorii, commonly known as the MacGregor huckleberry, is a low-growing shrub native to the western United States. It belongs to the Ericaceae family, which includes other well-known plants like blueberries and cranberries. The plant produces small, dark blue to black berries that are edible and often used in local cuisine. It thrives in acidic, well-drained soils and is typically found in open woodlands and rocky slopes. Vaccinium macgregorii plays an important ecological role by providing food for wildlife and supporting local biodiversity.
